Greetings,

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@f...> wrote:
> On Friday 16 July 2004 06:32 pm, cypherfox wrote:
> >  Greetings,
> >  [...deletia: unit vs. functional tests...]
> 
> So, perhaps the problem is that you are now past the
unit/programmer level 
> testing and are getting into the "functional" testing arena.  JUnit
was not 
> designed to work in this arena, though it does work quite well.

Exactly, I've come to that same point.  It does work QUITE well,
in fact, and one tweak to it lets it work perfectly for me, but I
can understand it being antithetical to the design.

In fact, that was what I was first asking, with way too many
words: what basic design principle of JUnit am I missing that
made it be written in a way that makes what I'm trying to do,
hard?

I have to admit, I work for a start-up with a very small QA staff (2).
In a much larger company, there would be white-box SQA to
build the higher level tests I'm building, but as a small company
developer, I feel the need to build 'programmer tests' that are a
*lot* more comprehensive in order to make sure the code is
really solid before I hand it off.

--  Morgan Schweers
